Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Story: I glanced at the clock, heart pounding as the angry client’s voice echoed through the nearly empty salon. She jabbed a finger at her hair, her words sharp and loud, demanding a fix before closing. My hands trembled as I tried to soothe her, promising to make it right, all while my phone buzzed in my pocket. I knew it was my husband—he’d been quiet all week, and tonight I’d promised we’d talk, really talk, about what was weighing on him. He needed me to listen, to be present, to share my own worries too. But here I was, trapped between the expectations of my job and my marriage. My client’s frustration demanded my full attention, but my mind kept drifting to home, to the conversation waiting for me. I felt torn, guilt pressing in from both sides, unsure how to be the wife my husband needed and the professional my client expected—all at the same time.
